Common HTML Elements

Here we describe commonly used HTML elements.

Navbar

To create a navbar, use the nav element and put your links within a list element.

This will style the navbar based on the width of the browser:

  • In small browsers, one list item will be displayed per row.

  • In medium browsers, two list items will be displayed per row.

  • In large browsers, all list items will be displayed on a single row.

Add the current_page class to note which page the user has currently selected. This will use the $nav-current-page-color to color that text. Otherwise, the framework uses $nav-text-color to color the text.

Here are all of the variables associated with navbar:

						
$nav-background-color
$nav-element-background-color
$nav-text-color
$nav-current-page-color
$nav-font-family
Here's the code made to make the sample nav bar below.

Navbar syntax
					
<nav>
  <ul>
    <li class="current_page">Current Page</li>
    <li><a href="#">Page 2</a></li>
    <li><a href="#">Page 3</a></li>
  </ul>
</nav>
  • Current Page
  • Page 2
  • Page 3

Content (aka Card/Panel/Tile)

Whatever you want to call it, these add a style onto the element that lets it pop out, as if you put the content on a card and placed it on the page. You can use the content-primary, content-secondary, or content-tertiary class to set the background color to the primary, secondary or tertiary color.

You can modify some of the Sass variables to control the look and feel of these elements.

						
$content-primary-bkg-color
$content-secondary-bkg-color
$content-tertiary-bkg-color

Content classes
						
<div class="row">
  <div class="content-primary col2">Primary Content</div>
  <div class="content-secondary col2">Secondary Content</div>
  <div class="content-tertiary col2">Tertiary Content</div>
</div>
Primary Content
Secondary Content
Tertiary Content

Buttons

Any button elements or anchor tags with the button class will be stylized. In this code example, we have a button and an anchor tag.

Here are the variables you can edit to change the look of the buttons:

						
$button-color
$button-corner-radius
$button-text-color

Button element and link
					
<div class="row">
  <div class="col3">
    <button>This is a button.</button>
  </div>
  <div class="col3">
    <a class="button">This link has the button class.</a>
  </div>
</div>
This link has the button class.

Codeblock

Preformated code blocks are useful when you don’t want any formatting or whitespace is important. You can see an example below.

These work off the pre and code elements, so you don’t need to add a class to style them.

These Sass variables affect code blocks, if you want to customize further.

						
$code-font
$codeblock-background-color

Here's the code used to make the codeblock.


Codeblock HTML
					
<div class="row">
  <aside class="col6">
    <pre>
      <code>
$code-font
$codeblock-background-color
      </code>
    </pre>
  </aside>
</div>
